QuestionJSON.Question: Kenya has developed a program that calculates both potential and kinetic energy when given mass, height, velocity and gravitational constant. Recently, they found an open-source code that also calculates change in energy. Instead of writing his own code for calculating change in energy, Kenya decides to use chunks of the open-source code in their program. What should Kenya do to ensure they respect intellectual property rights?
QuestionJSON.Answer1: Kenya can just copy the code and use it in their program without indicating where it came from.
QuestionJSON.Answer2: Kenya should try to rewrite the code in a different way, so it does not look like they copied it.
QuestionJSON.Answer3: Kenya needs to mention in their program that parts of their code are derived from the open-source code and provide a link to the original code.
QuestionJSON.Answer4: Since it is open-source, Kenya doesn't need to do anything as they are free to use the code in any way they want.
QuestionJSON.Explanation: Intellectual property rights should always be respected. Even if the code is open-source, it is professional decorum (and often required under the terms of use) to give proper attribution to the original creator or source.
